History of Present Illness:
60-year-old gentleman with laryngeal cancer, metastatic non
small cell ca [**1-13**] s/p taxol chemotherapy. Brain metastasis with
subdural hematoma s/p evacuation x 2. Recent admission [**Date range (1) 44643**]
with altered mental status thought to be secondary to overuse of
narcotics, and found to have a pathologic L femur fracture and
underwent ORIF.

throat cancer that was diagnosed in [**2137**].
Apparently treated with chemoradiation, the details of which we
are not sure of, and then was diagnosed with metastatic
non-small  cell CA in 01/[**2138**]. He underwent Taxol chemotherapy,
and also had complications related to metastatic brain tumor
that turned hemorrhagic for which he needed surgical evacuation
along with tumor resection on two occasions, the last one being
in [**3-/2140**] here at [**Hospital **] [**Hospital **] [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]. He also has a
history of PE and he is on anticoagulation for that.

In the ED vital signs 99% 4L, 112/56, 109, 30. CXR with large
left effusion with collapse of the left lower lobe and moderate
right effusion. Also redemonstrated are multiple pulmonary
masses. Overall, this study appears minimally changed from a CT
done two days prior. IP consulted. Patient started on
Vanc/Zosyn. Admitted to the ICU for further monitoring.

through [**7-13**] - mixed response then progression
5) received [**Doctor Last Name **]/5FU/LV [**Date range (1) 81221**] then progressed

s/p resection [**2140-2-7**]. path c/w undifferentiated large cell

7) developed left hip pain [**3-14**] and found to have metestatic

history of smoking. No EtoH or ilicit drugs. Has been ambulating
with walker at home. He does have a VNA.

Mother died at 67 of congestive heart failure, father died at 73
of asthma. He has two sisters who are in good health. He has
five brothers, one had skin cancer, which was taken care of and
it was not serious. He has one son who is 34 in good health who
has accompanied him today on today's evaluation.

CHEST (PORTABLE AP) Study Date of [**2140-5-5**] 11:43 AM:
IMPRESSION: Large left effusion with collapse of the left lower
lobe and moderate right effusion. Also redemonstrated are
multiple pulmonary masses. Overall, this study appears minimally
changed from a CT done two days prior.


Brief Hospital Course:
Assessment and Plan: This is a 60 yo M with a history of throat
cancer and presumed lung cancer, with metastases to brain and
bone who presents with tachypnea.

# Tachypnea: Patient had CT chest 2 days prior to admission that
showed bilateral pulmonary and pleural masses, effusions,
collaps, and lymphadenopathy. Extreme worsening in malignancy in
a short period. Patient is afebrile, without leukocytosis, but
started on Vanc/Zosyn in ED for potential post-obstructive
pneumonia. Patient has history of bilateral PEs, and is on
therapeutic lovenox. Initially patient wanted all measures
taken. Discussion with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] from IP. Given extent of
disease burden and impending intubation proceeding with
intubation did not seem appropriate. Lengthy discussion with the
family regarding goals of care. Discussed potential futility of
thoracentesis on pleural effusion as not likely to benefit his
state. Also patient with dose of lovenox in AM. Given metastatic
disease with such poor prognosis decision was made with family
to make the patient comfort measures. Antibiotics were
discontinued. I maintained the patient on stool softeners, and
keppra as I deemed this to be discomforting to the patient if he
would have a seizure or become constipated. Discussed pain and
sedation options with family and patient. He was tachypneic but
without increased cough, secretions or overt pain. He wanted to
be awake as much as possible to discuss with his family.
Patient was placed on comfort measures only, started on morphine
Q2 Hr IV, ativan Q2 hr, nebs for comfort.  Palliative Care was
consulted and measures were taken to set up home with hospice
per patient and family request.

# Metastatic Cancer: Patient with known throat cancer, and
presumed lung cancer, with history of mets to brain, bone, and
lung.  Care measures only taken as above.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 4253**], Dr.
[**Last Name (STitle) **], primary oncologists, were emailed to be kept abreast
of the situation.

# Bilateral PE: Unlikely source of tachypnea. Patient had been
on lovenox since PE, lovenox discontinued

# FEN: No IVF, regular diet

# CODE: CMO

# Comm: sons, patient [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 81226**]

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital for shortness of breath. This
is felt to be related to progression of your cancer involving
your lungs. The decision was made to focus care on keeping you
comfortable and you will be going home with hospice care.
